facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 60 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 60 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 24, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in Government Appeal No. 1379 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 24, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in Government Appeal No. 1379 of 1962. C. Misra and O.P. Rana, for the appellant. 1. P. Goyal, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, J.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed the appeal of the State against the judgment of the Sessions Judge allowing the appeal of the respondent and acquitting him.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the Allahabad High Court dismissing the appeal of the State against the judgment of the Sessions Judge allowing the appeal of the respondent and acquitting him.

facts.text: The respondent obtained permits under the Iron and Steel Control Order, 1956 for about 28 tons of iron, including 6 tons of rods, 15½ tons of joints and 2 tons of G.C. Sheets.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent obtained permits under the Iron and Steel  Control  Order, 1956--hereinafter referred to as the Control Order for about 28 tons of iron, including 6 tons of rods, 151/2 tons of joints and 2 tons of G.C. Sheets.

facts.text: The respondent is alleged to have purchased these articles on the basis of the above permits between July 1957 and March 1958.

anchor.surface_text: He is alleged to have purchased these articles on the basis of the above permits between July 1957 and March 1958. The permits were obtained on three applications made by the respondent.

facts.text: The permits were obtained on three applications made by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The permits were obtained on three applications made by the respondent. Only two applications are in the printed record. The first application is dated May 23, 1957, and is addressed to the Provincial Iron and Steel Controller, Kanpur, through the District Magistrate, Deoria.

facts.text: First application dated May 23, 1957, addressed to the Provincial Iron and Steel Controller, Kanpur, through the District Magistrate, Deoria.

anchor.surface_text: The first application is dated May 23, 1957, and is addressed to the Provincial Iron and Steel Controller, Kanpur, through the District Magistrate, Deoria. In this application the respondent stated that he was a political sufferer and he was companystructing a public temple for which he required five tons of M.S. Round and eight tons of Girder.

facts.text: In first application, respondent stated he was a political sufferer and constructing a public temple requiring five tons of M.S. Round and eight tons of Girder.

anchor.surface_text: In this application the respondent stated that he was a political sufferer and he was companystructing a public temple for which he required five tons of M.S. Round and eight tons of Girder. He further stated that the requirements were number available at Deoria and as such the application should be companysidered and forwarded to the Controller for companysideration and orders.

facts.text: First application forwarded, duly recommended, by the District Supply Officer, Deoria, and permit given by the Controller.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that this application was forwarded, duly recommended, by the District Supply Officer. Deoria, and ultimately a permit was given to him by the Controller.

facts.text: Second application dated September 7, 1957, stating political sufferer constructing public temple and dharamshala.

anchor.surface_text: He made another application dated September 7, 1957. In this application he again stated that he was a political sufferer and he was companystructing a public temple and dharamshala for which he required certain quantities of iron.

facts.text: Second application recommended and forwarded, permit given.

anchor.surface_text: He further stated that the requirements were number available at Deoria and as such the application should be forwarded to the Controller. This application was also recommended and forwarded and ultimately a permit was given to him.

facts.text: On January 2, 1958, the accused made another application Ex. Ka 9 and a permit was given by the District Supply Officer.

anchor.surface_text: On January 2, 1958, the accused made another application  Ex. Ka 9--not available in the printed record  and a permit was given to him by the District Supply Officer himself.

facts.text: Original permits not printed in the record.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that the original permits are number printed in the record, and, therefore, we have number been able to see for ourselves as to what are the exact companyditions companytained in the permits.

facts.text: Prosecution case: respondent after obtaining materials did not construct any temple or dharamshala at Barhaj Bazar or any other place.

anchor.surface_text: It is the case of the prosecution that the respondent after obtaining the materials sanctioned to him under the permits did number companystruct any temple or dharamshala building at Barhaj Bazar or at any other place.

facts.text: Barhaj Bazar is the place where respondent lives and applications mention this address.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that Barhaj Bazar is the place where he lives and the applications which are in the record also mention this address.

facts.text: Respondent's reply to Magistrate: iron used in temple at mauza Tinbari, P.S. Madhuban, district Azamgarh, his place of residence.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Magistrate who tried the case the respondent was put the following question It is alleged that the iron obtained under the permits mentioned in questions 2, 3 and 4 was number utilised for the purpose for which it was taken. What have you to say in this respect? The respondents reply was No. Whatever iron 1 got, I used it in the temple situate in mauza Tinbari, P.S. Madhubam district Azamgarh, which is my place of residence as well.

facts.text: Before Magistrate, accused admitted purchasing about 17 tons of iron.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Magistrate the accused had admitted to have purchased about 17 tons of iron.

facts.text: Magistrate held accused purchased at least one ton more from Mishri Lal, P.W. 7, total at least 18 tons.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate held it proved that the accused had atleast purchased one ton more from one Mishri Lal, P.W. 7. Thus, he came to the companyclusion that the accused had purchased at least 18 tons of iron.

facts.text: Magistrate held only 3/4 ton of rods utilised in building constructed at Tinhari between 1943-52.

anchor.surface_text: He further held that on the evidence it was clear that only 3/4 ton of rods had been utilised in the building companystructed at Tinhari, but as the building had been companystructed between 1943--52, numberportion of the iron obtained by the accused had been utilised for the purpose for which it was procured.

facts.text: Magistrate held accused disposed of iron wrongfully at Kanpur, did not bring to Barhaj Bazar or Tinhari.

anchor.surface_text: He further held that the accused had disposed of the iron wrongfully at Kanpur and did number even bring the same to Barhaj Bazar or Tinhar.

facts.text: Magistrate held respondent contravened cl. 7 of Control Order.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly he held that the respondent had companytravened the provisions of cl. 7 of the Control Order.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held barring small quantity, remaining iron not utilised in temple or dharmashala at Tinhari.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge held that barring a very small quantity of iron, the remaining quantity that was received by the respondent had number been utilised in the temple or dharmashala at Tinhari.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held not proved that respondent sold excess at Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: Differing from the Magistrate, he held that it was number proved by any evidence that the respondent had actually sold the excess quantity at Kanpur.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted respondent, no contravention of cl. 7.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly he held that there had been numbercontravention of cl. 7 of the Control Order.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Srivastava J dismissed State appeal, no contravention of cl. 7.

anchor.surface_text: The State appealed to the High Court. Srivastava, J. dismissed the appeal holding that there had been numbercontravention of cl. 7 of the Control Order.

facts.text: High Court held not proved respondent used the iron obtained.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the first companydition had number been fulfilled because it had number been proved that the respondent had used the iron which he had obtained on the basis of the permit.

facts.text: Permit condition: materials used only for purpose asked for and given.

anchor.surface_text: This companydition was that the materials required against the permit will be used only for the purpose for which it was asked for and has been given.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no contravention of cl. 7 by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In companyclusion we hold that it has number been established that the respondent had used the iron acquired by him in companytravention of cl. 7 of the Control Order.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds applications do not disclose construction at particular place.

anchor.surface_text: But even if we look at the applications, which are in the printed record, the purpose mentioned is only companystruction of a temple, in the application dated May 23, 1957, and temple and dharamshala in the application dated September 7, 1957. These applications do number disclose that the respondent wanted to companystruct the temple and dharamshala at any particular place.

facts.text: No orders shown empowering District Magistrate only for works in district.

anchor.surface_text: However, numberorders showing the jurisdiction of the District Magistrate in respect of this matter has been shown to us, and we are unable to companyclude from the applications that the purpose was companystruction of a temple and dharamshala in the district of Deoria alone.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds respondent has not contravened cl. 7.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 24, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in Government Appeal No. 1379 of 1962.

This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the Allahabad High Court dismissing the appeal of the State against the judgment of the Sessions Judge allowing the appeal of the respondent and acquitting him.

issues.text: Whether the respondent contravened clause 7 of the Iron and Steel Control Order, 1956 by not utilising the iron for the permitted purpose

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly he held that the respondent had contravened the provisions of cl. 7 of the Control Order. The respondent filed an appeal before the Sessions Judge. The Sessions Judge held that barring a very small quantity of iron, the remaining quantity that was received by the respondent had not been utilised in the temple or dharmashala at Tinhari. Differing from the Magistrate, he held that it was not proved by any evidence that the respondent had actually sold the excess quantity at Kanpur. He then observed that in the absence of any such evidence the possibility of the appellant retaining the iron at some other place is not completely excluded. Then construing cl. 7 of the Control Order, he observed that in the aforesaid section there is no mention that the iron purchased should be utilised at any particular place or within a particular period.

issues.text: Whether 'use' in clause 7 of the Control Order includes mere non-use, keeping or storing of iron otherwise than in accordance with permit conditions

anchor.surface_text: he says that we should give a wide construction to the word use in cl. 7. Clause 5 and the relevant portion of cl. 7 of the Control Order are as follows Disposals. No person, who acquires iron or steel under clause 4. or producer shall dispose of or agree to dispose of or export or agree to export from any place to which this Order extends any iron or steel, except in accordance with the conditions contained or incorporated in a special or general written order of the Controller. Use of Iron and Steel to conform to conditions governing acquisition. A person acquiring iron or steel in accordance with the provisions of cl. 4 shall not use the iron or steel otherwise than in accordance with any conditions contained or incorporated in the document which was the authority for the acquisition

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion we hold that it has not been established that the respondent had used the iron acquired by him in contravention of cl. 7 of the Control Order. The learned counsel further urges that the High Court erred in holding that the application cannot be referred to for the purpose of construing the conditions appearing in the permit, the condition being that the materials acquired against a permit will be used only for the purpose for which it was asked for and has been given. He says that the expression the purpose for which it was asked for refers back to the application, and the expression has been given refers back to the Order.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly he held that there had been no contravention of cl. 7 of the Control Order. The State appealed to the High Court. Srivastava, J. dismissed the appeal holding that there had been no contravention of cl. 7 of the Control Order. According to him, two essentials are necessary before there can be contravention of cl. 7. In the first place the iron and steel should be used secondly it should be used otherwise than in accordance with the conditions contained or incorporated in the document which was the authority for the acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: London County Council v. Wood 1 , but we do number derive any assistance from that case. The head-note brings out the point decided in that case as follows The Highways and Locomotives Act, 1878, provides by s. 32 that A companyntry authority maymakeby-laws for granting annual licences to locomotives used within their companyntry. And by a by-law made by the London County Council under that section it was provided that No locomotive shall be used on any highway within the companynty of London until an annual licence for the use of the same shall have been obtained from the companyncil by the owner thereof-- Held, that a steam-roller which was number at the time being employed in road-making, but was merely passing through the companynty to a destination outside was being used within the companyntry within the meaning of the section and the by-law.

anchor.surface_text: But even if we look at the applications, which are in the printed record, the purpose mentioned is only construction of a temple, in the application dated May 23, 1957, and temple and dharamshala in the application dated September 7, 1957. These applications do number disclose that the respondent wanted to construct the temple and dharamshala at any particular place.
Accordingly we hold that the respondent has number companytravened cl.
